Editorial for special issue on interactive virtual environments for serious games
Download PDF
Download PDF
  • S.I. : VR and AR Serious Games
  • Published: 10 March 2018

Editorial for special issue on interactive virtual environments for serious games

  • Fotis Liarokapis1 &
  • Alun Evans2 

Virtual Reality volume 22, pages89–90(2018)Cite this article

  • 559 Accesses

  • Metrics details

For much of the general public, ‘Virtual Reality’ is almost synonymous with ‘gaming’. In the early 1990s, gamers would pay premium prices to experience VR in the arcade, using the systems produced by the Virtuality Group, such as the 1000CS and 1000SD. These machines, which cost upwards of 60,000$ at the time, were for many people the first taste of virtual reality.

It is hardly an exaggeration to say, however, that the overall experience of these machines was not that impressive. 3D rendering technology had not yet reached the level of maturity and realism required; and game design was not yet aware of the specific challenges presented by virtual reality (particularly with regards to camera movement and motion sickness).

The disappointing experience provided by such machines, along with other relative failures of the time such as Nintendo’s VirtualBoy, and the Sega VR headset, meant that VR gradually faded from the public view; only really being kept alive in academic circles (and thanks, in no small part, to journals such as Virtual Reality).

It was the games industry, however, that brought VR back into the public eye. 2010 saw the launch of the Oculus Rift project, supported initially by crowdfunding, and then by Facebook. With ‘other’ technology (real-time rendering, screen quality, bandwidth, etc.) now having reached sufficient maturity, the games industry has invested heavily in VR and bought back into the public eye.

Where, then, does the academic community stand in relation to this massive injection of cash and resulting research? In the last decade we have seen technological breakthroughs in games-related fields (such as graphics and physics) shift from being university-lead to industry-lead; as research talent moves into well-funded games companies with dedicated R + D teams. The onus on the academic community, then, is to focus on those fields of research that the industry ignores. In recent years, the concept of ‘serious games’—more correctly termed games for serious applications—is one such field. It is clear that game design, technology and methods are advancing faster than at any point in history, and the ability to apply this new breakthrough in applications beyond the entertainment industry has led to an array of interesting research.

Serious games are computer games that are not limited to the aim of providing entertainment that allow for collaborative use of 2D/3D spaces but are also used for different purposes in a number of application domains. By sharing the same technical infrastructure, the state-of-the-art in Serious Game technology is identical to that of the entertainment games technology. Users’ engagement is crucial to serious games and this is the key factor that can provide positive effects.

Some of the most characteristic strengths could be generalised as being in the areas of: education and learning; communication and collaboration; interaction and presentation of information and entertainment. Moreover, serious games typically incorporate gamification which only focuses on increasing the motivation factor of users.

The term ‘Serious Games’ covers a broad range of applications from Adobe Flash-based applications to fully immersive 3D environments where users interact with large volumes of data through sophisticated digital interfaces. Specifically, they can exist in the form of: simple web-based solutions; online virtual environments; mashup applications; advanced computer games; mixed reality games or mobile applications. The shift towards immersive world applications being used to support, among others, education and training activities, marks the beginning of new challenges that present considerable scope for collaborative and multi-disciplinary research solutions, as well as opportunities for innovative development.

During the past few years, there has been an explosion of serious games in the above areas and in particular in interactive virtual and augmented reality environments, which is a subset of mixed reality games. It is expected that a lot of fascinating and novel new applications will arise in the next few years. On the other hand, the emergence of serious or non-leisure uses of games technologies and virtual reality applications have been dramatic over the past few years. This special issue focuses on the broad area of Interactive Virtual Environments for Serious Games.

This special issue aims to meet the challenges of the community that work around research into games and game technologies to present novel virtual world infrastructure developments. The main focus of this special issue is to address this challenge by particularly encouraging submissions related to the application and impact of new technologies related to Augmented Reality (AR), Virtual Reality (VR) and advanced Human–Machine Interaction applied in serious games. The selected papers encapsulate the above technologies through novel approaches and case studies.

Bruno et al. (2017) presented a virtual diving system based on a virtual reality application for the exploitation of the Underwater Cultural Heritage. The virtual diving experience has been designed to entertain users, but its added pedagogical value is explicitly emphasised too. The virtual diving system provides general and historical-cultural contents, but also information about the flora and fauna of the specific submerged site to the users.

Koutsabasis and Vosinakis (2017) presented the design, development and evaluation of a kinesthetic application of sculpturing Cycladic figurines, which places the user at the role of an ancient craftsman who creates a figurine with bare-hand movements in a simplified virtual environment. Authors identified several benefits as well as challenges of designing kinesthetic interactions in museums and we report on design issues that need to be taken into account in similar applications.

Kerous et al. (2017) presented a systematic review of electroencephalography (EEG)-based brain–computer interfaces (BCIs) that are used in the area of video games. The paper examines the progress of BCI research with regard to games and shows that gaming applications offer numerous advantages by orienting BCI to concerns and expectations of a gaming application. Different BCI paradigms are investigated, and future directions are discussed.

Jiang et al. (2018) presented the design and implementation of a 3D game with the support of virtual reality equipment which imitates the process of a lifeboat launch, involving both tractor manoeuvres and boat operations. The key modules of the game are designed based on physical simulations to give the players enhanced plausible cognition and enjoyable interaction. The game is proven to be very promising for future professional training and it serves the educational purpose of awareness of the safety issues for general public while being entertaining.

Liang et al. (2018) proposed a semantic framework to model the construction of interactive animation and promote animation assets reuse in a systematic and standardised way. As its ontological implementation, two domain-specific ontologies for the hand-gesture-based interaction and animation data repository have been developed in the context of Chinese traditional shadow play art. Finally, prototype of interactive Chinese shadow play performance system using deep motion sensor device was presented as the usage example.

References

    Google Scholar 

  2. Jiang M, Lan W, Chang J, Dodwell M, Kekins J, Yang HJ, Tong RF, Zhang JJ (2018) A game prototype for understanding the safety issues of a lifeboat launch. Virtual Real. https://doi.org/10.1007/s10055-018-0334-7

    Google Scholar 

  3. Kerous B, Skola F, Liarokapis F (2017) EEG-based BCI and video games: a progress report. Virtual Real. https://doi.org/10.1007/s10055-017-0328-x

    Google Scholar 

  4. Koutsabasis P, Vosinakis S (2017) Kinesthetic interactions in museums: conveying cultural heritage by making use of ancient tools and (re-) constructing artworks. Virtual Real. https://doi.org/10.1007/s10055-017-0325-0

    Google Scholar 

  5. Liang H, Deng S, Chang J, Zhang JJ, Chen C, Tong R (2018) Semantic framework for interactive animation generation and its application in virtual shadow play performance. Virtual Real. https://doi.org/10.1007/s10055-018-0333-8
